course.subject: OCES
course.name: Marine Biology
course.description: Survey of the major marine living organisms; their habitat and community structures; trophic interactions and the marine ecosystem.

reviews.author: Shin, Woo-hong
reviews.title: Similar to LIFS2060
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1: Introduction to Marine Environment  
Introduction to Marine Environment Liu
Physical and chemical oceanography Liu

Part 2: The Organisms of the Sea
Marine prokaryotes: Bacteria and Archaea Liu
Marine viruses: living or non-living Liu
Marine algae: plant-like Liu
Marine protozoa: animal-like Liu
Multicellularity and the simplest animals Wu
Cnidaria and Ctenophora (coral, jellyfish, and comb jellies) Wu
Mollusca I (snails) Wu
Mollusca II (clams) Wu
Mollusca III (octopus and squids) Wu
Marine worms and beyond: Lophotrochozoa Wu
The largest phylum: Arthropoda Wu
Almost vertebrates: Echinodermata, Hemichordata, Cephalochordata, and Urochordata Wu
Marine Fishes Liu
Marine Mammals Liu

Part 3:  Structure and Function of Marine Ecosystem
Primary productivity Liu
Zooplankton and food web Liu
Carbon cycle and global warming Liu
Sandy beach and mudflat ecology Liu
Rocky shore ecology Liu
Subtidal ecosystems Liu
Estuary Liu
Coral reef Liu
Deep Sea Ecosystem Liu

As long as you attend lectures it wouldn't cause any problem.
If you have completed LIFS2060, this course would be more manageable for you, as LIFS2060 primarily focuses on taxonomy, which overlaps with the content covered in this lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both are faithful and passionate professors.
Professor Liu Hongbin often delves into concepts beyond the scope of the topic, but there's no need to worry as those will not be tested in the exam.
Professor Wu Longjun is incredibly passionate and dedicated, always striving to provide detailed explanations.
reviews.comment_workload:
To be honest, this course requires a significant amount of content to be memorized. Therefore, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to individuals who excel primarily in memorization skills.
Only Two Exams

reviews.author: wdawa
reviews.title: Not a easy course, but you still can get very good grade
reviews.comment_content:
In this course, you can studied the most common species you can found in the ocean, include:
-common oceanic microorganisms like algae, virus and bacteria.
-invertebrate: sponge, jellyfish, octopus, sea anemone and  etc.
-vertebrate: fish and marine mammals.
-Different ecosystems: Rocky shore, coral reefs, mudflat etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: In this year, 2/3 of the course taught by Prof. LIU, including the microorganisms and ecosystem, Prof. WU put his focus on the marine animals.  Both of them taught well,  but WU's course is much worthy to attend. He is a very good lecturer who knows how to make the content interesting and easy to understand. LIU makes nice and clean powerpoint for his teaching too, however he is not a really good speaker and it is easy to lose your attention during his lecture.But never mind, you can get a good grade  by watching his slides only ;)
reviews.comment_workload: There are only midterm and final exam for this course, the final conducted 10% more because of larger amount of content compared to midterm and the content tested in midterm will not be tested in the final. Both midterm and final conducted 30-40 MC questions, and 2-4 short essay question. There are no attendance requirement.( I skipped almost half of the lectures) , so the workload is quite low compared to other OCES courses
